file_content.text: The reserve soldiers are working out very well.
And you say this squad--this group--managed to hold off the entire Talz commando force?
And you say this Sith held off the entire Talz force single-handed?
And you say the entire Talz force was held off single-handedly by some bounty hunter?
And you say the entire Talz force was held off by one person? And they're not even a Sith?
It sounds incredible, to be sure, but here, I'll let you talk directly.
You all have the thanks of the entire base. We were just expressing our amazement.
My lord, we cannot express our gratitude.
Sir, our gratitude is overwhelming. We were just talking about you.
May I introduce Moff Braynor, overseer of the Hoth system, among others.
I am surprised you'd take an interest in this humble base.
What's the occasion?
Your base is key to our activities on Hoth, and if not for you, it would have been lost.
Good to meet you.
I heard you telling the Moff the good news.
Then our plan fully succeeded.
Yes, you've saved us from giving a much bleaker report.
If not for you, Dorn Base would have been lost, and all the outposts that depend on it.
It is for that reason I ask you your opinion.
Would you say Commander Tritan or Chiss Captain Yudrass was more instrumental in the base's defense?
Commander Tritan's leadership has been forthright and direct.
Commander Tritan.
I expected such a response. Tritan works diligently, if not always wisely.
He is hereby promoted to colonel, responsible for the welfare of Dorn Base until further notice.
I wish you well, Colonel Tritan.
Congratulations.
Uh... thank you. This is... this is really something. I will do my best, Moff Braynor.
Colonel Tritan will have my full support, as always.
See that he does. That will be all.
That's a lot of responsibility, wouldn't you say, Commander?
That's quite a promotion.
He has served us well under fire, and the soldiers respect him. That is paramount.
I hope we will not have another leadership crisis any time soon, Colonel Tritan.
Don't make me regret this.
Never again. This base will be as organized as a repair droid's toolbox.
Never again, my lord.
Never again, sir. You can count on me.
And I will not disappoint you, Moff Braynor.
Your recommendation has meant the world to me, but I must turn my attentions to my base immediately.
Sir... there is still the matter of the pirates at Leth Outpost.
Yes, of course. Captain Revar lost a facility of some sort, yes? If you're in the area you might want to look into it. Terrible pirates out there.
Captain Yudrass's advice formed most of our key strategies. We relied on him heavily.
Chiss Captain Yudrass.
That is as I expected. Very well.
Captain Yudrass, you are now Colonel Yudrass. I am putting the base's welfare in your hands until further notice.
It seems you have broken down a few barriers, Colonel Yudrass.
Congratulations.
I... thank you. This is unprecedented.
I don't believe I've heard of a Chiss ranking so high before.
That's quite a promotion.
It is unprecedented, but Captain Yudrass is well-known for his skill and judgment.
It is one thing to promote an alien, it is another to expect humans to serve him.
The humans won't like this.
Better to have soldiers alive and grumbling than happy and dead. Success is the only currency here.
I trust you know the consequences of failure at this level.
Don't mess this up.
Believe me, Colonel Vannis's example has made that clear.
You do me great honor, Moff Braynor. I will have the base at inspection quality immediately.
Sir, if I might ask--do you think the enlisted men will have a problem taking orders from Colonel Yudrass?
You mean will they refuse orders from a Chiss? They will at first. Then they will be made examples.
You could demonstrate your commitment by helping win the men over.
Yudrass will need your help.
That is an excellent idea. I will begin immediately. Thank you, Moff Braynor, Colonel Yudrass.
Make it clear what happens to the disobedient, and you will do fine.
Fear will keep them in line.
That is correct. The fastest remedies to insubordination are force and fear.
I will keep that in mind, Moff Braynor. Thank you.
That will be all.
Well... that went better than expected.
I don't care. Let's move on.
Now the base must recuperate from its losses and replenish its personnel.
I will leave you to discuss this amongst yourselves.
I cannot thank you enough for the recommendation. Chiss will see the Imperial Army differently now. It will help win their loyalty.
I suppose we should be happy we don't have pirate problems here.
Yes... he's referring to another security failure. Captain Revar at Leth Outpost lost a reactor substation to the White Maw pirates.
We have asked much of you, but Captain Revar has not, and his soldiers desperately need relief at the Leth Outpost. If you have the time, look in on them.
Quick! To the power station!
We'll prepare the base. You provoke the Talz.
Those Talz will soon know what it means to cross Dorn Base.
We are having deep morale issues in the forward outpost. I must show them that we can triumph without Colonel Vannis.
Now is the time for reprisals. These chittering animals will not get away with this.
I want ten of the Republic to suffer for every one of ours dead. I want every last Talz wiped out, their heads on sticks out in the frost.
I will find them, and they will die.
Done.
If we are lucky, it will be that simple, but we should plan for less than ideal circumstances.
Their destruction is assured. I only need their location.
Dead Talz, coming right up.
Location is important, but an estimate of their numbers doubly so.
When I'm done, this place will be carpeted in Talz fur.
No problem.
A fine image. Now we need a plan that matches it.
I don't normally do massacres. But today isn't normal.
I can do that.
Yes, but any campaign of extermination must be predicated by knowing how many of the enemy there are.
Anything you'd like to add?
Yudrass, what do you think?
The main thrust of the plan is sensible, but given our limited knowledge, I suggest the plan be... refined before use.
If it were that easy, you'd have done it already.
It may not be so simple.
True. We have the proper intelligence, now we need a plan of action.
A covert action is advisable, or we'll end up wiping out one group and causing the rest to go into hiding.
I have data arrays we could install in their communicators link. If we did that, we could locate and estimate their numbers before we hit them.
Killing is reliable. Technology isn't.
We take their heads.
That sounds like a lesson gleaned from a life far more interesting than mine.
They weren't carrying handheld comms. They've probably got way-stations. I can bug those.
We hit their communications.
This sounds plausible. As much as I hate to admit it, Yudrass is usually right about these things.
Commander! Come in, Commander!
Go ahead, Scout Five.
We've found a nest of Talz on the ice lake--too many to engage. Transmitting coordinates now.
Our luck is changing. If you can get those arrays into whatever they're using for communications, we'll soon know what we need.
Perfect timing. Brutally slaughtering a few dozen should sow fear throughout their little cabal.
When you're done, report to the forward outpost. It's closer to the lake, and the men there can see your success in person.
I found Colonel Vannis. He was dead, murdered by Republic Talz.
Yes, we heard as much from the men you freed. Terrifying, cunning beasts.
It seems our new responsibilities are as permanent as we feared, wouldn't you say, Commander?
Talz. That would make sense. Cold-adapted, Republic-aligned. I've not killed their kind before... what about you, Commander?
What? Yes, of course.
The base awaits your orders, Commander.
We're scanning the frequencies for the colonel. So far, nothing but silence.
Your advice boils down to doing nothing, and that I cannot do.
Sir, I respect your bravery, but if you see this through personally you will be dead, and whose leadership will we have then?
Ah, we've been awaiting your arrival. This is Commander Tritan, and I am known by the core name Yudrass.
My lord, we're glad you've arrived. May I introduce Commander Tritan, and myself, a humble captain, core name Yudrass.
If Command's description is correct, I believe you're the bounty hunter sent to assist us. This is Commander Tritan, and I am Yudrass.
Ah, the agent. It's good you've arrived. This is Commander Tritan, and I am his advisor, Yudrass.
Sir, I believe this is the visitor Command told us about. Greetings, this is Commander Tritan, and my core name is Yudrass.
Lieutenant Halpern sent word you would be coming, and we've never had greater need of you.
Colonel Vannis, the commander of this base, is missing. We fear he's dead, along with all the most experienced men from this base.
It is pleasant to be among such fine company.
Greetings, brother.
We have been here longer than the Empire. It was our breakthrough that first alerted them to the Republic presence.
The Chiss have proven their worth to us, Yudrass especially, during this emergency.
I expected a commander's counsel to be more... exclusive.
You don't need alien advice.
Yudrass and the other Chiss at the base are not part of our rank structure. He is merely advising during this emergency.
Not many non-humans have the ear of a base commander.
Nice to see an alien presence.
Yes, well--my influence is entirely up to Commander Tritan.
Our Chiss allies have valuable knowledge of the planet. Yudrass is advising me during this emergency.
An emergency that grows more dire every moment the colonel is missing. This was the distress call we received.
Tell me the problem.
To lose one officer is a casualty. To lose them all sounds like a coup.
What treachery is this?
I assure you, the last thing I wanted was leadership of this base. I had zero choice in the matter.
The colonel went out to investigate evidence of a possible spy probe near the ice lake. He was under heavy guard.
We received a distress call. It was obvious he found... trouble.
Scout One to Dorn Base! Heavy casualties! Taking heavy casualties! We're under attack. We can't see the--aaaaah!
Recordings don't frighten me. I'll go see if I can find out what happened.
I'll go take a look.
What on this world could take out an armed group of officers?
Do you have any suspects?
Besides the Republic, there are wampas, pirates--mostly aliens unafraid of the Empire.
Sounds like a lost cause.
This is what I was trying to tell the commander. We've lost two rescue teams already.
But we can't simply cower in our base when the mission is to damage and exhaust the Republic.
And our men can't do it. Commander. This visit is a gift to us from fate.
Ten enemies or ten thousand, I stand ready to strike them down.
I am always ready.
The first priority is to find Colonel Vannis, dead or alive. After that, feel free to wreak as much vengeance as you like.
Whoever is behind this will be nothing but a blot on the snow.
They will die before me.
Indeed. I have heard of the power of Sith. I only hope that you have not come too late.
If a man-tracker is what you need, you've got the right person.
I'll find Vannis.
Excellent. You'll find footprints easy to follow on Hoth... for about five minutes until blowing snow obscures them.
You will soon know all you need to. You have my word.
I can discover anything.
Good. Intel is the priority. We must learn what happened to Vannis... and rescue him if he still lives.
I will go if the ranking officer wishes.
Mind your position, Yudrass.
Yudrass presumes much, but he's right. You're the colonel's only chance.
Sounds like a big problem. Can you tell it to me again in credits?
What's this worth?
We'll pay any price you name. Find Colonel Vannis or at least tell us what we're up against.
Our best-case scenario is that Colonel Vannis's communications tipped off the Republic, and he's gone quiet.
But if I were out in that cold, I'd have called for a rescue. If you can find the colonel, everyone on this base is in your debt.
This is Commander Tritan's duty. Let him wander around in the snow looking for a lost cause.
I'm not going. [Refuse quest]
But we know the risks of this mission to be immense.
Yudrass, this is no challenge a student of military history cannot overcome. We must ask ourselves, "What would Malak do?"
I haven't the time.
